awd_titl_txt: Dimensions NASA: Collaborative Research: The biogeography and evolution of drought tolerance in grasses
awd_abstract_narration:
Drought is a pervasive factor that structures grasslands worldwide. Yet little is known about the genetic basis of drought tolerance, how drought-tolerance has evolved, how it is distributed geographically, and what its potential role is in determining future grassland productivity. In this research, the investigators will determine physiological drought tolerance and associated anatomical and physiological traits for 400 species of grass distributed across eight major evolutionary groups and broad geographic and environmental ranges. To better understand the genetics of grasses, gene expression will be examined as well as root and leaf anatomy, morphology, and physiology. With new sequence data complementing current efforts, the phylogenetic relationships among the 400 species and their environmental niche spaces will be determined. The research will also parameterize models of global productivity in the context of drought, coupling data on drought tolerance with gas exchange and environmental data, which will be critical in modeling responses of vegetation to future climate change.

Understanding the different dimensions of drought tolerance and photosynthesis will contribute broadly to our understanding of grasslands in a way that could impact everything from crop selection to predictions of future global function. Additionally, this project will recruit underrepresented individuals at the graduate and post-doctoral level, will contribute to multiple public datasets, and will develop educational materials such as a temporary exhibit on the phylogeny of grasses and grass roots to the new Flint Hills Discovery Center in Manhattan, KS.

por.por_cntn:
Grasslands are major agro-ecosystems across the earth. Drought is a regular feature of these grasslands, yet not enough is known about the genetic basis of drought tolerance, how it evolved, and what its potential role is in determining the productivity of future grasslands. 

In this project, physiological drought tolerance and the underlying genomics for over 300 species of grasses representing all grasslands on earth and from all major grass subgroups were determined. We produced three sets of specific results.

1) Gene expression patterns at multiple time points during increasing water stress and immediately after recovery from stress were characterized in a model pasture species commonly called Sheep fescue. Across our catalogue of all possible expressed genes, 117 drought responsive genes were identified.

2) Botanical relationships among over 300 species of grasses were characterized. Experimental artifacts were seen when data gaps, which are commonly left in data matrices, were included in the analysis. We recommend removal of all such data gaps to improve accuracy in future analyses.

3) Drought tolerance as an indicator of water use efficiency was mapped in detail across over 300 grasses in a genomics framework. Multiple independent origins of drought tolerance were identified and were sometimes found to be independent of other so-called "preadaptations," suggesting a wider range of grass species among which drought tolerance could arise. 

Understanding the different dimensions of drought tolerance and photosynthesis contributed broadly to our knowledge of grasslands in a way that impacts everything from crop selection to the management of restored prairies. 

This project trained undergraduate and graduate STEM students who completed their college degrees and now hold professional positions from college teachers to cancer researchers. Our big science experimental datasets were made publicly available in scientific repositories. Our results were published in peer-reviewed, open access journals. Our research can be the basis for use in predicting responses of grassland plant communities to future changes in climate.
